gemini_pro.summary:
The Knowledge Graph accurately captures the product families, material availability, and basic dimensions from the PDF. However, there is a systemic issue with products that have multiple length variants (GDB, GDMI, GDC, GDC Flex, GDMI Flex). For these families, the graph only stores one weight value (usually the shorter/lighter version, but inconsistently the longer/heavier version for GDMI), ignoring the alternative configuration. This is a major deficiency for logistics and structural calculations.

Additionally, the graph lacks cartridge count data for the majority of sizes in the GDC and Flex families, only defining rules for 600x600 and 900x600 modules, whereas the PDF provides comprehensive tables for all sizes. Correcting these two areas (dual-weight support and complete cartridge capacity rules) is essential for the graph to serve as a reliable configuration engine.

findings.description: Graph allows material FZ for GDMI FLEX, but the PDF explicitly says GDMI FLEX is made in ZM only (not stainless), i.e., not FZ/AZ.
findings.pdf_says: PDF (GDMI FLEX page): "GDMI FLEX tillverkas vanligen i ZM. Ej i rostfritt." and the material icons shown are FZ, AZ, ZM (icons), but the text restricts to ZM only.
findings.recommendation: Set GDMI FLEX material availability to ZM only (or model a rule: standard ZM, optional AZ/FZ only if explicitly supported—PDF text indicates not). If you keep icons-based availability, reconcile by confirming with product owner and then encode the correct allowed set.

findings.description: Graph material availability is incomplete vs PDF. PDF indicates GDMI is available in ZM and also AZ as standard offering; PDF also notes possibility of stainless. Graph only lists AZ and ZM (default ZM), missing the stated (rare) stainless possibility if that is meant to be orderable.
findings.pdf_says: PDF (GDMI page): "GDMI tillverkas vanligen i ZM. Ei i Rostfritt." and icons show AZ and ZM.
findings.recommendation: Clarify whether 'Ej i rostfritt' is intended (likely 'Ej i rostfritt' = not in stainless). If stainless is NOT available, correct the PDF-interpretation note in graph metadata. If stainless IS available as exception, add RF/SF as special-order materials with constraints.

findings.description: Graph includes 'Max Chlorine PPM' per material, but the PDF provides only corrosion classes (C3/C4/C5/C5.1) and material grades; it does not specify chlorine ppm limits. This introduces unsupported numeric constraints that could drive wrong recommendations.
findings.pdf_says: PDF Material page lists: FZ Z275 C3; AZ C4; RF 1.4301 C5; SF 1.4404 C5.1; ZM310 C5. No chlorine ppm values shown.
findings.graph_says: Material table includes Max Chlorine PPM: AZ 5, FZ 0, RF 50, SF 500, ZM 10
findings.recommendation: Remove 'Max Chlorine PPM' or mark as 'not-from-catalog' with source and confidence; do not use it for automated selection unless backed by a referenced standard/datasheet.

findings.description: Graph claims PT is available in AZ, SF, ZM; PDF table only shows FZ as standard material and states other materials are on request, not enumerated.
findings.pdf_says: PDF PT page: PT size list shows material FZ; text: "Övriga material, storlekar eller längder tillverkas på begäran."
findings.graph_says: Available materials: FZ (default), AZ, SF, ZM
findings.recommendation: Change PT to 'FZ standard' and model 'other materials on request' without enumerating unless confirmed; or keep enumerations but flag as 'special order' not in catalog.

findings.description: Graph lists EXL available in FZ/AZ/RF/ZM, but PDF specifies EXL is usually made in Aluzink (AZ) and does not list other materials.
findings.pdf_says: PDF EXL page: "Utförs vanligen i aluzink. Korrosivitets klass C4."
findings.graph_says: Available materials: FZ, AZ (default), RF, ZM
findings.recommendation: Restrict EXL materials to AZ only, or model other materials explicitly as non-catalog special orders with evidence.

findings.description: Graph asserts construction type 'BOLTED' with source PENDING_MIKAEL; PDF does not state bolted/welded. This is an unverified attribute that may mislead downstream logic.

findings.recommendation: Either (a) remove/blank this property until confirmed, or (b) attach an explicit non-PDF source document reference and mark confidence.

findings.description: Graph service access is set to FRONT_RAIL, but PDF describes a service door (servicelucka) with hinges and door lock (typical side access), not a rail/front pull-out service concept. It does mention an 'utdragbar kolfilterplatta' (pull-out carbon plate), but that is not the service door orientation.

findings.recommendation: Split concepts: (1) service door orientation (side-hinged) and (2) internal pull-out tray/plate feature. Set service access to SIDE_HINGED (or equivalent) and add a feature 'pull-out carbon plate'.

findings.description: Graph code format uses a space: "EXL-{width} {material}". PDF example uses hyphen: "EXL-600 AZ" in the table header but the example line shows "EXL-600 AZ" (space before material) while family codes elsewhere are hyphen-delimited. This is inconsistent and likely should be standardized.

findings.recommendation: Standardize to exact PDF formatting: 'EXL-{width} {material}' is acceptable if you treat the space as canonical; otherwise normalize to 'EXL-{width}-{material}' but store a 'pdf_example_code' separately.

findings.description: Graph captures 'max filter depth' at family length-variant level, but does not encode the 25mm frame requirement for EXL locking and for compact/pocket filters noted in PDF ("EXL ... för ... 25 mm ram"). This missing constraint can produce incompatible filter recommendations.

openai.summary:
Across the core cabinet families (GDP, GDB, GDMI, GDC, GDC FLEX, GDMI FLEX), the graph matches most of the per-size airflow values shown in the PDF tables, and it includes essentially all families pictured in the catalog (with one notable exception: 'PTT' appears in the table of contents but is not present in the graph). The biggest integrity risk is that the graph frequently collapses multi-variant tabular data (especially weights and length ranges) into a single record per WxH, which loses information that the PDF explicitly provides per length variant (e.g., GDB/GDMI/GDC/GDC FLEX all have two weight columns). This is critical because weight and length are selection/engineering outputs and should be variant-specific.

Material modeling also needs correction: several families/parts list materials that are not supported by the PDF (PT enumerating multiple materials; EXL listing non-AZ materials; GDMI FLEX allowing FZ/AZ despite the text stating ZM only). In addition, the transitions (PT/TT) are not correctly modeled because the graph drops required per-row attributes (nippelmått and TT standard length), and PT duplicates 600x600 without distinguishing the different nippelmått options. Finally, some construction/service-access metadata is asserted without PDF support and should be either removed or clearly marked as non-catalog, to avoid contaminating recommendation logic.

findings.description: GDMI page 11 shows only AZ and ZM material icons. The text explicitly states 'Ej i Rostfritt' (Not in stainless steel). The graph correctly has only AZ and ZM. However, the default material in the example code is AZ, but the graph lists ZM as default. The PDF example code shows GDMI-600x600-600-R-PG-AZ, suggesting AZ is the standard/default.
findings.pdf_says: Example code uses AZ as default material (page 11: GDMI-600x600-600-R-PG-AZ). Text says 'tillverkas vanligen i ZM'.
findings.graph_says: ZM listed as default material for GDMI
findings.recommendation: Verify which is the true default. The text says 'vanligen i ZM' but the example code uses AZ. Consider marking both as possible defaults or clarifying with product management.

The PDF text says 'levereras i isolerat dubbelmantlat utförande i förzinkad plåt' but this refers to the inner construction, not the material option. The material icons only show AZ and ZM, which is correct in the graph.
findings.pdf_says: Material icons: AZ, ZM only (page 11)
findings.recommendation: No action needed - graph is correct on this point.

However, the example code shows GDMI-FLEX-600x600-850-R-PG-FZ, suggesting FZ is the default. The graph does not indicate which is default for GDMI FLEX.

anthropic_opus.summary:
The Knowledge Graph captures all 12 product families from the PDF catalog and has generally accurate data for sizes, airflow ratings, and material availability. The GDP, GDB, GDMI, GDC, GDC FLEX, GDMI FLEX, BFF, PFF, PT, TT, EXL, and Filter Profil families are all present with correct size counts matching the PDF tables. Airflow values and primary weight data are accurate across all product families.

The most significant gaps are in the dual-weight data and length variant completeness. Every housing family (GDB, GDMI, GDC, GDC FLEX, GDMI FLEX) has two length options with corresponding PG and Fläns dimensions, but the graph only stores one length per variant without the Fläns (+50mm) dimension. Similarly, each family provides two weight columns (one per length), but the graph only stores one weight per size. This means roughly half of all weight data is missing. Additionally, cartridge count data for GDC, GDC FLEX, and GDMI FLEX families is incomplete - only 2 out of 12, 2 out of 6, and 2 out of 8 sizes respectively have CapacityRule entries.

Filter module configuration data (1/4, 1/2, 1/1 module breakdowns) for GDB and GDMI is entirely absent from the graph, as is the GDP-to-PFF frame mapping. These are important for filter selection and sizing. The GDB 1800x900 weight value of 63 kg in the graph does not match the PDF's 36 kg (likely a PDF typo), which should be verified with engineering. Overall, the graph provides a solid foundation but needs completion of secondary weight data, cartridge counts, filter module configurations, and structured length variant properties to fully represent the catalog.

However, the PDF explicitly displays material icons for FZ, AZ, and ZM on Page 18 (top left). 'Usually' does not imply 'Only', and the icons confirm availability of FZ and AZ.

gemini_pro.final_assessment: The Knowledge Graph has significant deficiencies regarding dimensional variants and weight data. Multiple evaluators confirmed that the graph consistently fails to capture the dual-length nature of the product lines (PG vs Fläns dimensions) and the corresponding weight differences, which is critical for logistics. Additionally, the graph contains hallucinated data points (Chlorine PPM, 'Pending' construction sources) that must be removed. While the material availability is mostly correct (despite some evaluator confusion over Swedish negation), the lack of comprehensive cartridge count rules and the missing weight variants renders the graph unreliable for precise configuration.

challenged_findings.reason: PDF 'Sortiment' does not state GDC filter max depth 650mm for the 900/950 cabinet; that 650mm depth applies to GDB and GDMI long-bag variants. For GDC, the Sortiment table lists only lengths (750/800 and 900/950) and does not present max filter depth. Therefore this is not a graph-vs-PDF discrepancy based on page 3; it’s an internal inconsistency hypothesis.

Text says 'GDMI FLEX tillverkas vanligen i ZM. Ej i rostfritt.' which indicates typical material is ZM and excludes stainless, but does not exclude FZ/AZ (and the example directly contradicts ZM-only).

new_findings.description: Graph may be over-claiming test scope for GDC vs the PDF. For GDP/GDB/GDMI the PDF states leakage through housing, strength, and filter bypass leakage per EN 15727 and EN 1886. For GDC (patron cabinet) the PDF states leakage through housing and strength (no filter bypass leakage claim). If the graph copies the bypass-leakage claim to all families, it is incorrect for GDC (and likely GDC FLEX / GDMI FLEX too).

new_findings.graph_says: Test/standard attributes appear uniform across families (often including filter bypass leakage) rather than family-specific.
new_findings.recommendation: Make test-claim attributes family-specific: only include 'filter bypass leakage' where explicitly stated (GDP/GDB/GDMI). For GDC/GDC FLEX/GDMI FLEX keep 'housing leakage + strength' unless bypass is explicitly documented.

openai.final_assessment: Peer review confirms the largest objective gaps are configuration-variant modeling issues: multiple families (GDB, GDMI, GDC, GDC FLEX, GDMI FLEX) have dual length variants in the catalog (PG vs flange) and correspondingly dual weights, but the graph often stores only one weight/length set. Additionally, GDC cartridge counts/capacity rules are incomplete versus the catalog tables. One of my own critical material findings (GDMI FLEX being ZM-only) is disproved by the GDMI FLEX page showing FZ/AZ/ZM icons and an FZ example code, so that finding is retracted. Remaining concerns include non-catalog attributes (e.g., chlorine ppm limits; construction type marked 'PENDING_MIKAEL') and potential over-generalization of test claims across families. Overall the graph captures the product lineup and many basics, but it is not yet reliable as a configuration/logistics engine until variant-specific dimensions/weights/capacities are fully modeled and non-PDF assumptions are quarantined.

However, the PDF page 18 clearly shows THREE material icons: FZ, AZ, and ZM. The text says 'vanligen i ZM' (usually in ZM) which indicates ZM is the default/most common, not the only option. 'Ej i rostfritt' means RF and SF are excluded, not FZ and AZ. The material icons are the definitive indicator of availability across the entire catalog. The example code on page 18 even uses FZ: 'GDMI-FLEX-600x600-850-R-PG-FZ'.

The graph is CORRECT to exclude RF/SF for GDMI. The PDF page 11 shows only AZ and ZM icons, and the text explicitly states stainless is not available. anthropic_opus.final_assessment:
After peer review, there is strong consensus across all three evaluators on several systemic issues with the knowledge graph. The most significant and universally confirmed issue is the incomplete weight data: all product families with dual length variants (GDB, GDMI, GDC, GDC FLEX, GDMI FLEX) only store one weight value instead of two. This was independently identified by all three evaluators and represents a critical data gap for logistics and engineering calculations.

The second major consensus area is the incomplete representation of length variants. The PDF consistently shows dual lengths (PG/Fläns) for all multi-length families, but the graph only captures the PG dimension. The chlorine PPM data flagged by OpenAI is a valid concern - these values are not sourced from the catalog and could drive incorrect material recommendations.

On material availability, I challenged OpenAI's finding that GDMI FLEX should be ZM-only, as the PDF page 18 clearly shows FZ, AZ, and ZM icons and the example code uses FZ. The word 'vanligen' (usually) indicates default preference, not exclusivity. Similarly, OpenAI's suggestion that EXL should be AZ-only contradicts the material icons shown on page 23.

The cartridge count gap identified by Gemini Pro is significant - the graph apparently only has capacity rules for a subset of GDC sizes while the PDF provides comprehensive data for all sizes. The construction type 'BOLTED' with source 'PENDING_MIKAEL' flagged by both Gemini and OpenAI represents unverified data that should be marked as provisional.

Overall, the graph captures the basic product structure well but has systematic gaps in: (1) dual-weight storage, (2) complete length variant representation, (3) cartridge count completeness, (4) unsourced data attributes like chlorine PPM, and (5) nuanced product differences like testing scope and hardware specifications. I estimate the graph at approximately 68% accuracy when considering both structural correctness and data completeness.

findings.recommendation: Create per-length-variant weight records for all 27 GDB sizes. Each WxH should have weights for both 550/600 and 750/800 lengths.

findings.description: Graph includes 'Max Chlorine PPM' per material (AZ 5, FZ 0, RF 50, SF 500, ZM 10), but the PDF provides only corrosion classes (C3/C4/C5/C5.1) and material grades. No chlorine ppm limits appear anywhere in the catalog. This introduces unsupported numeric constraints that could drive incorrect material recommendations.
findings.pdf_says: Page 4: FZ Z275 C3; AZ C4; RF 1.4301 C5; SF 1.4404 C5.1; ZM310 C5. No chlorine ppm values anywhere in the catalog.
findings.graph_says: Material table includes Max Chlorine PPM: AZ 5, FZ 0, RF 50, SF 500, ZM 10.

findings.description: Graph asserts construction type 'BOLTED' with source 'PENDING_MIKAEL' for GDP, GDB, GDC, and GDC FLEX. The PDF does not state bolted vs welded construction for any of these families. This is an unverified attribute from a non-catalog source that may mislead downstream logic.
findings.pdf_says: Pages 5, 8, 14, 16: Describe single-wall uninsulated housing, door types, locks, and testing standards, but do not specify bolted vs welded construction.
findings.graph_says: Construction: BOLTED (source: PENDING_MIKAEL) for GDP, GDB, GDC, GDC FLEX.
findings.recommendation: Either remove the construction type property until confirmed by engineering, or mark it explicitly as 'unverified/non-catalog' with low confidence so it is not used in automated logic.

findings.description: Graph PT dimension modules store only WxH, repeating 600x600 three times without capturing the required nippelmått (pipe diameter) that distinguishes the variants. The PDF PT table lists 5 distinct size+nippelmått combinations. Without nippelmått, the three 600x600 entries are indistinguishable.
findings.recommendation: Model PT variants with a composite key including nippelmått (e.g., PT 600x600 Ø315/Ø400/Ø500). Add nippelmått as a required property.

findings.description: Graph TT dimension modules store only WxH, missing the per-row Ø d nippelmått and Std. längd values that are explicitly tabulated in the PDF. These are essential for ordering and installation.
findings.pdf_says: Page 22 TT table includes columns: Storlek, Ø d nippelmått, Std. längd, Material. Example: 300x300 Ø250 L300; 600x600 Ø500 L450; 600x900 Ø630 L600; etc. 35 rows total.
findings.graph_says: TT sizes only store WxH with no nippelmått or std length. Graph has 44 entries vs PDF's 35.
findings.recommendation: Extend TT dimension module schema to include nippelmått (diameter) and std_length_mm. Populate every row exactly as in PDF. Audit and remove the 9 extra entries not in the PDF.

findings.description: Graph claims PT is available in FZ, AZ, SF, ZM. The PDF table only shows FZ as standard material and states 'Övriga material, storlekar eller längder tillverkas på begäran' (other materials on request). The graph should not enumerate non-standard materials as if they are catalog offerings.

findings.recommendation: Set PT to FZ as the only standard material. Either remove AZ/SF/ZM or flag them explicitly as 'special order / on request' with a note that they are not catalog-standard.

findings.description: The GDP table on page 6 includes 'Anta PFF Ramar' (number of PFF frames) and 'Exaktmått PFF-Ram Bredd x Höjd' columns mapping GDP sizes to specific PFF frame sizes and counts. This relationship is not captured in the graph, nor are the allowed frame depths (25, 50, 100mm) modeled as selectable options.
findings.pdf_says: Page 6: GDP 600x600 = 1 PFF frame 592x592. GDP 1500x1500 = 4 PFF frames 742x742. Standard frame depths: 25, 50, 100mm. Example code: GDP-600x600-50-R-PG-FZ.

findings.description: The PDF INNEHÅLL (table of contents) on page 2 lists 'PTT' as a separate item under Övergång & Tillbehör, alongside 'TT'. The graph contains 'PT' and 'TT' but no 'PTT' family. It is unclear whether PTT is a distinct product or a catalog label for PT.

findings.description: The polisfilter option ('Förmonterad filterskena för polisfilter') for the longer housing variants is not properly modeled in the graph. The PDF describes this as a key feature of the 900/950mm (GDC/GDC FLEX) and 1100/1150mm (GDMI FLEX) lengths, with distinct use cases: (a) 450mm cylinder + polisfilter, or (b) 600mm cylinder without polisfilter.
findings.pdf_says: Pages 14, 16, 18: 'Option: Skåp L= 900/950mm Förmonterad filterskena för polisfilter'. GDC notes: 'Längd 750/800 för 450 mm cylinder', 'Längd 900/950 för 450 mm cylinder + polisfilter', 'Längd 900/950 för 600 mm cylinder'.
findings.graph_says: Options include polisfilter feature marked as None / not properly coded.
findings.recommendation: Add a structured option 'POLISFILTER_READY' tied to the long length variant. Model the three configuration intents: (a) short housing for 450mm cylinder, (b) long housing for 450mm cylinder + polisfilter, (c) long housing for 600mm cylinder.

findings.description: GDP, GDB, and GDMI are tested for housing leakage, strength, AND filter bypass leakage per EN 15727:2010 and EN 1886:2007. However, GDC, GDC FLEX, and GDMI FLEX are only tested for housing leakage and strength (no filter bypass leakage claim). If the graph applies the same test scope to all families, it over-claims for the patron filter cabinets.
findings.pdf_says: Page 14 GDC: 'testat avseende läckage genom hölje och hållfasthet' (no 'filter bypass läckage'). Page 5 GDP: includes 'filter bypass läckage'. Page 8 GDB: includes 'filter bypass läckage'.
findings.graph_says: Test/standard attributes appear uniform across families rather than family-specific.
findings.recommendation: Make test-claim attributes family-specific. Only include 'filter bypass leakage' for GDP/GDB/GDMI. For GDC/GDC FLEX/GDMI FLEX, limit to 'housing leakage + strength'.

findings.description: GDB 1800x900 weight for 550/600 length shows 36 kg in the PDF, which appears anomalously low compared to surrounding values (1800x600=47kg, 1800x1200=70kg for 550/600). This is likely a PDF typo. The graph reportedly has 63 kg for this entry, which does not match the PDF but may be more realistic.

findings.description: The PDF explicitly states that EXL excenterlåsning is for 'kompakt och påsfilter med 25 mm ram' (compact and pocket filters with 25mm frame). This 25mm frame requirement is a compatibility constraint that is not captured in the graph, which could lead to incompatible filter recommendations.
findings.pdf_says: Pages 8, 11: 'EXL excenterlåsning för kompakt och påsfilter med 25 mm ram.'
findings.graph_says: No explicit constraint tying EXL/these housings to 25mm filter frame requirement.
findings.recommendation: Add a compatibility constraint: supported_filter_frame_thickness_mm = 25 for GDB/GDMI when using EXL. Model EXL as standard equipment for these families.

findings.description: The graph has 44 TT dimension modules but the PDF page 22 lists only 35 TT sizes. The graph appears to have 9 extra entries not present in the catalog.
findings.pdf_says: Page 22: 35 TT sizes listed (from 300x300 to 2400x2400).
findings.recommendation: Audit all TT sizes against the PDF table on page 22. Remove any sizes not present in the catalog or mark them as non-catalog additions with source documentation.

recommendations: P1 CRITICAL: Add dual-weight support for all multi-length housing families (GDB, GDMI, GDC, GDC FLEX, GDMI FLEX). Each WxH size must have weight records for both length variants. This affects ~96 size entries across 5 families.
P2 CRITICAL: Remove or quarantine 'Max Chlorine PPM' values from the material table. These are not sourced from the catalog and could drive incorrect automated material selection.

P3 CRITICAL: Add nippelmått (pipe diameter) and standard length properties to PT and TT dimension modules. Without these, PT has indistinguishable duplicate entries and TT loses essential ordering information.
P4 MAJOR: Complete cartridge count CapacityRule data for GDC (10 missing sizes), GDC FLEX (4 missing sizes), and GDMI FLEX (6 missing sizes) from the PDF tables.
P5 MAJOR: Model PG/Fläns length pairs explicitly for all multi-length families instead of storing only the PG dimension.
P6 MAJOR: Add filter module configuration data (1/4, 1/2, 1/1 module breakdowns) for GDB (27 sizes) and GDMI (43 sizes) from the PDF tables.
P7 MAJOR: Add GDP-to-PFF frame mapping (frame count and exact frame dimensions) for all 34 GDP sizes from the page 6 table.
P8 MAJOR: Remove or mark as 'unverified/non-catalog' the construction type 'BOLTED' (source: PENDING_MIKAEL) for GDP, GDB, GDC, and GDC FLEX.
P9 MAJOR: Properly model the polisfilter option for GDC/GDC FLEX/GDMI FLEX long-length variants with structured configuration rules.
P10 MAJOR: Restrict PT material availability to FZ standard; flag other materials as 'on request' only.
P11 MINOR: Audit TT sizes (44 in graph vs 35 in PDF) and remove non-catalog entries. Make test-claim attributes family-specific (bypass leakage only for GDP/GDB/GDMI).
final_report.summary:
The knowledge graph captures all 12 product families from the MANN+HUMMEL HVAC filter cabinet catalog and has generally accurate data for sizes, airflow ratings, and primary material availability. GDP airflow values (34 sizes), GDB airflow values (27 sizes), GDMI airflow values (43 sizes), BFF sizes/weights, and PFF sizes/airflow are all verified as correct. The basic product structure, family relationships, and most material availability rules are sound.

However, the graph has a systemic and critical deficiency in how it handles multi-variant products. Every housing family with dual length options (GDB, GDMI, GDC, GDC FLEX, GDMI FLEX) stores only one weight value per size instead of two, meaning approximately half of all weight data across ~96 size entries is missing. Length variants are simplified to single values (e.g., 550mm instead of 550/600mm PG/Fläns), losing the connection type dimension. Cartridge count data for patron filter cabinets is severely incomplete, with only 2 out of 12 GDC sizes, 2 out of 6 GDC FLEX sizes, and 2 out of 8 GDMI FLEX sizes having CapacityRule entries. The transition products (PT/TT) are missing essential per-row attributes (nippelmått and standard length) that are required for ordering.

Additionally, the graph contains data not sourced from the catalog—most notably 'Max Chlorine PPM' values per material and 'BOLTED' construction types with a pending verification source—which could contaminate automated recommendation logic. Filter module breakdown data (1/4, 1/2, 1/1 modules) for GDB and GDMI, and GDP-to-PFF frame mappings, are entirely absent despite being explicitly tabulated in the catalog. Addressing the dual-weight gap, completing cartridge counts, adding transition product attributes, and quarantining non-catalog data are the highest-priority actions to make the graph reliable as a configuration and logistics engine.
